channel.title: F3d
channel.description:
[b]7/19/09 message: Im starting to work on my engine more and completing it so i've updated this topic and will keep it updated.[/b]
First, i know for a fact no one here will think i made it, due to the scarred history i have left myself in this section.
Second, i did not rip this code, i will appropriately accredit people that have helped me towards the bottom.
I have been working on my engine for about 2 months now, i didn't start physically writing it until the end of Christmas, early January.
Also, this isn't meant for RS models, its just, they have so many colors and polys it would be a challenge to practice loading them than cubes..
[u][b]Includes:[/b][/u]
[ul][li]Backface culling[/li] [li]Z-Depth sorting[/li] [li]Grid[/li] [li]Axis[/li] [li]Simple loading UI[/li] [li]Simple Rotation[/li] [li]Wireframe[/li] [li]Perspective[/li][/ul]
[img]http://img29.imageshack.us/img29/4691/perspective.png[/img]
[img]http://img6.imageshack.us/img6/7598/viewerstuffqk2.png[/img]
[img]http://img7.imageshack.us/img7/102/screeniefinalpt3.png[/img]
I wont release the source until maybe tomorrow or Thursday because... [quote="Iamadam, post:10, topic:206294"][center][i]Your code hurts my eyes. They are currently bleeding. Learn to indent it.[/i][/center][/quote] Its indented, but, :) Its messy.
Credits: Taharok (Z-Depth, understanding of matrices) Telenubby (ArrayLists) Newbiehacker (the rotation) [code] Matrix3D.rotateY(Math.toRadians(-(e.getX() - lastPoint.x))); Matrix3D.rotateX(Math.toRadians(-(e.getY() - lastPoint.y))); [/code] lel

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=345386.msg2875179#msg2875179 date=1248005890]
Thats a very close copy of JmonkeyEngine , i know since i wrote few basic games using it:
www.jmonkeyengine.com

-> I suggest you don’t Release Source unless you give most credits to jmonkeyengine incase its true.[/quote]
the only relation this has to jME is that its written in java, but jME is just an abstraction for native rendering libraries

Read full topic

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=345386.msg2875327#msg2875327 date=1248015539]

[quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=345386.msg2875179#msg2875179 date=1248005890]
Thats a very close copy of JmonkeyEngine , i know since i wrote few basic games using it:
www.jmonkeyengine.com

-> I suggest you don’t Release Source unless you give most credits to jmonkeyengine incase its true.

I wrote this myself before i even found out about jmonkey…
[/quote]
I was not really sure , but as i see i can see even method’s arguments and stuff similar to that of jmonkey’s in the example that you’ve posted, check with your friends that you’v credited. [/quote]

Then you need to learn what 3D engines are all about. JMonkeyEngine is 3rd party software, yet his engine is entirely standalone. Plus, JME uses both LWJGL and JOGL to do it’s rendering. In case you are unaware, both of those are also third party software. They are initially built for hardware-based rendering, but have support for software-based as well (on such machines as laptops, where their graphics cards don’t have the OpenGL or DirectX libraries).

So to be completely honest, you need to do several weeks more of research before accusing someone of doing something wrong, especially when they probably have months more experience than you in this language.

Read full topic

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Basically, I just didn’t explain normals the same way.

Though looking at the way I worded it I see why he gave that explanation.

I was trying to say the face’s normals are pointing away from the camera.

Read full topic

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:46, topic:261538”]A normal is a vector that is perpendicular to the face. This is all mathematical:

en.wikipedia.org

Normal (geometry)

In geometry, a normal is an object such as a line or vector that is perpendicular to a given object. For example, in two dimensions, the normal line to a curve at a given point is the line perpendicular to the tangent line to the curve at the point. In three dimensions, a surface normal, or simply normal, to a surface at a point P is a vector that is perpendicular to the tangent plane to that surface at P. The word "normal" is also used as an adjective: a line normal to a plane, the normal compo...

And the idea of detecting backfaces is checking the relationship between the normal of the checked face and the camera vector.[/quote]
Is that not what he said?

Read full topic

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:45, topic:261538”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=345386.msg2687678#msg2687678 date=1235772448]

Backface culling? Or camera based optimization?

Backface culling is when the backs of the normals are invisible. So if you put the camera inside of the character, you would see nothing because all the normals are facing the opposite way.

Camera based optimization is not viewing, rendering, or thinking about polygons which are invisible to the camera at a current time.

At least, that’s what both of them have always been called when I’ve learned about them.

Either way, this is cool.

Backface culling is the actual act of culling the faces which are invisible to the camera. That’s how I learned it.
[/quote]

Backfaces are just that, faces (normals) that are facing away from the camera so their backs are seen.
Which is what I said.

I was just saying that backface culling isn’t what I think Frell was trying to describe, unless I’m getting his description of it wrong.[/quote]

A normal is a vector that is perpendicular to the face. This is all mathematical:

en.wikipedia.org

Normal (geometry)

In geometry, a normal is an object such as a line or vector that is perpendicular to a given object. For example, in two dimensions, the normal line to a curve at a given point is the line perpendicular to the tangent line to the curve at the point. In three dimensions, a surface normal, or simply normal, to a surface at a point P is a vector that is perpendicular to the tangent plane to that surface at P. The word "normal" is also used as an adjective: a line normal to a plane, the normal compo...

And the idea of detecting backfaces is checking the relationship between the normal of the checked face and the camera vector.

Read full topic

item.title: F3d
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:44, topic:261538”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=345386.msg2687050#msg2687050 date=1235743725]

Backface culling? Or camera based optimization?

Backface culling is when the backs of the normals are invisible. So if you put the camera inside of the character, you would see nothing because all the normals are facing the opposite way.

Camera based optimization is not viewing, rendering, or thinking about polygons which are invisible to the camera at a current time.

At least, that’s what both of them have always been called when I’ve learned about them.

Either way, this is cool.
[/quote]

Backface culling is the actual act of culling the faces which are invisible to the camera. That’s how I learned it.[/quote]

Backfaces are just that, faces (normals) that are facing away from the camera so their backs are seen.
Which is what I said.

I was just saying that backface culling isn’t what I think Frell was trying to describe, unless I’m getting his description of it wrong.

Read full topic

At least, that’s what both of them have always been called when I’ve learned about them.
